Prohibition and Repeal
Jack Daniel's gains up Brown-Forman income

Alcohol prohibition ended today in 1933

Kim D. Kolarik, kkolarik@courier-journal.com, Louisville 2:20 p.m. EST December 5, 2014
Buy Photo

Last Warning - Stop, Look, Listen. The day before the start of Prohibition in Louisville.(Photo: The Courier-Journal)Buy Photo

11 CONNECT 10 TWEETLINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE

An odd period came to an end on this day in 1933. Prohibition lasted form 1920-1933 and was a time when it was illegal to produce, transport or sell alcohol. There were some exclusions to prohibition for medical and religious purposes.

Check out "Last Call: The Rise and Fall of Prohibition" by Daniel Okrent. In great detail he takes the reader through the long period of time to pass prohibition and the cultural forces at work leading to the passage. Not surprisingly, the issues centered much on race, ethnicity and religious belief.

Ken Burns and Lynn also produced an incredible documentary called "Prohibition." You can catch it on Netflix.

PBS also has a series called "Nation of Drunkards." In that series, writer Pete Hammill writes: "Virtually every part of the constitution is about expanding human freedom except Prohibition, in which human freedom was being limited. When people cross the line between our essential character as Americans and some other superseding vision of what we should be, then we get in trouble."

Most distilleries in Kentucky were shuttered. Buffalo Trace distillery remained open during prohibition.

Last Warning - Stop, Look, Listen. The day before the start of Prohibition in Louisville. (Photo: The Courier-Journal)
